learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of intersecting lines and their properties.
Students will be able to identify and measure angles formed by intersecting lines.
Students will learn about linear pairs and vertically opposite angles.
Students will understand the concept of parallel lines and their properties.
Students will be able to identify and draw parallel lines in different situations.
Students will learn to recognize and mark perpendicular lines using mathematical notation.

content_blocks.text: When a pair of lines meet each other at a point on a plane surface, we say that the lines intersect each other.
When two lines intersect each other and form four angles, labelled a, b, c and d, as in Fig. 5.2, then ∠a and ∠c are equal, and ∠b and ∠d are equal!
Draw two lines on a plain sheet of paper so that they intersect. Measure the four angles formed with a protractor.
Since straight angles measure 180°, we must have ∠a + ∠b = ∠a + ∠d = 180°. Hence, ∠b and ∠d are always equal.
Linear pairs always add up to 180°.
Vertically opposite angles are always equal.
Parallel lines are lines that lie on the same plane and never meet, no matter how far they are extended.
To identify parallel lines, look for lines that have the same slope and never intersect. You can also use the notation > to show that a set of lines is parallel.
For example, in Fig. 5.6, the lines a, d, e, c, g, b, f, i, and h appear to be parallel.
Perpendicular lines are lines that intersect at a right angle (90°).
To mark perpendicular lines, use a square symbol to indicate the right angle between them.
For example, in Fig. 5.9, the lines p, q, and r are perpendicular to each other.

topic_name: Linear Pairs and Vertically Opposite Angles
learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of linear pairs and vertically opposite angles.
Students will be able to identify and measure linear pairs and vertically opposite angles.
Students will learn to justify the equality of vertically opposite angles using a proof.

content_blocks.text: Linear pairs: ∠a and ∠b, ∠c and ∠d, etc. Vertically opposite angles: ∠b and ∠d, ∠a and ∠c, etc.
When two lines intersect, vertically opposite angles are equal. This can be justified using a proof in mathematics.
List all the linear pairs and vertically opposite angles you observe in Fig. 5.3:
Measurement errors and variation in line thickness can affect the accuracy of measurements.
Perpendicular lines: a pair of lines that intersect each other at right angles (90°)
In Fig. 5.4, lines l and m are perpendicular to each other.

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of perpendicular lines.
Students will be able to identify and draw perpendicular lines.
Students will learn to recognize the properties of perpendicular lines.

content_blocks.text: Perpendicular lines: a pair of lines that intersect each other at right angles (90°)
If two lines intersect and all four angles are equal, then each angle must be a right angle (90°).
In Fig. 5.4, lines l and m are perpendicular to each other.

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of parallel lines.
Students will be able to identify and draw parallel lines.
Students will learn to recognize the properties of parallel lines.
Students will understand the concept of parallel lines and their properties.
Students will be able to identify and draw parallel lines using a ruler and a set square.
Students will learn to recognize corresponding angles formed by a transversal on parallel lines.

content_blocks.text: Parallel lines: a pair of lines that lie on the same plane and do not meet however far we extend
Lines that do not seem likely to intersect each other are called parallel lines.
In the pictures above, the lines do not seem likely to intersect each other.
Parallel lines are lines that lie in the same plane and never intersect, no matter how far they are extended.
When a transversal intersects two parallel lines, the corresponding angles formed are equal to each other.
Draw a pair of parallel lines using a ruler and a set square. Measure the corresponding angles formed by a transversal and verify that they are equal.
If the corresponding angles formed by a transversal on a pair of lines are equal, then the pair of lines are parallel to each other.
Draw a transversal intersecting two lines such that one pair of corresponding angles is equal. Measure the angles with a protractor and verify that they are equal.
A set square is a tool used to draw perpendicular lines and angles.
To draw a pair of parallel lines using a ruler and a set square, draw a line and then use the set square to draw two lines perpendicular to the first line.
Draw two parallel lines using the long side of the set square as shown in Fig. 5.22.

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of parallel lines and transversals.
Students will be able to identify and draw parallel lines and transversals.
Students will learn to recognize corresponding angles formed by a transversal.
Students will be able to identify corresponding angles and alternate angles.
Students will learn to use the properties of parallel lines and transversals to solve problems.
Students will learn to apply the properties of parallel lines and transversals to solve problems.

content_blocks.text: Parallel lines are lines that lie in the same plane and do not intersect, no matter how far they are extended.
A transversal is a line that intersects two or more lines at distinct points.
Draw a line l and a transversal t intersecting it at point X. Measure ∠a formed by lines l and t (let us say it is 60°).
When a transversal intersects two lines, it forms eight angles with a maximum of four distinct angle measures.
Corresponding angles are angles in the same relative position in two or more lines intersected by a transversal.
Draw a pair of lines and a transversal such that they form two distinct angles.
Parallel lines are lines that lie in the same plane and never intersect, no matter how far they are extended. A transversal is a line that intersects two or more lines at distinct points.

When a transversal intersects two parallel lines, it forms corresponding angles that are equal. Alternate angles are also equal, and can be found by identifying the corresponding angle and then finding the vertically opposite angle.

In Fig. 5.26, parallel lines l and m are intersected by the transversal t. If ∠6 is 135°, what are the measures of the other angles? ∠6 is 135°, so ∠2 is also 135°, because it is the corresponding angle of ∠6 and the lines l and m are parallel. ∠8 is 135°, because it is the vertically opposite angle of ∠6. ∠4 is 135° because it is the corresponding angle of ∠8.

We can find the measure of ∠d if we know ∠b because they are vertically opposite angles. Remember, vertically opposite angles are equal. What is the measure of ∠b? It is 120° because it is the corresponding angle of ∠f. So, ∠d also measures 120°.
In Fig. 5.25, if ∠f is 120° what is the measure of its alternate angle ∠d? We can find the measure of ∠d if we know ∠b because they are vertically opposite angles.
Parallel lines are lines that lie in the same plane and never intersect, no matter how far they are extended.
When a transversal intersects two parallel lines, it forms corresponding angles, alternate interior angles, and alternate exterior angles.
In the figure below, line l is parallel to line m. If ∠1 = 60°, find the measure of ∠5.
In the figure below, line l is parallel to line m. If ∠2 = 80°, find the measure of ∠6.
In the figure below, line l is parallel to line m. If ∠3 = 40°, find the measure of ∠7.
In the figure below, line l is parallel to line m. If ∠4 = 50°, find the measure of ∠8.
In the figure below, line l is parallel to line m. If ∠5 = 70°, find the measure of ∠9.
In the figure below, line l is parallel to line m. If ∠6 = 90°, find the measure of ∠10.
In the figure below, line l is parallel to line m. If ∠7 = 60°, find the measure of ∠11.
In the figure below, line l is parallel to line m. If ∠8 = 80°, find the measure of ∠12.

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of corresponding angles and their properties.
Students will be able to identify and measure corresponding angles in different scenarios.
Students will learn to apply the concept of corresponding angles to solve problems involving parallel lines and transversals.

content_blocks.text: Corresponding angles are angles that are formed by a transversal intersecting two or more lines and are on the same side of the transversal.
When a transversal intersects two or more lines, it forms corresponding angles on the same side of the transversal. These angles are equal in measure.
Example 1: In Fig. 5.26, lines l and m are parallel. If ∠8 is 135°, then ∠2 is also 135° because they are corresponding angles.
Example 2: In Fig. 5.27, lines l and m are intersected by the transversal t. If ∠a is 120° and ∠f is 70°, are lines l and m parallel to each other?
Example 3: In Fig. 5.28, parallel lines l and m are intersected by the transversal t. If ∠3 is 50°, what is the measure of ∠6?
Example 4: In Fig. 5.29, line segment AB is parallel to CD and AD is parallel to BC. ∠DAC is 65° and ∠ADC is 60°. What are the measures of angles ∠CAB, ∠ABC, and ∠BCD?

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of linear pairs and their properties.
Students will be able to identify and measure linear pairs in different scenarios.
Students will learn to apply the concept of linear pairs to solve problems involving parallel lines and transversals.

content_blocks.text: Linear pairs are two angles that are adjacent to each other and form a straight line.
When two lines intersect, they form linear pairs of angles. These angles are supplementary to each other.
Example 1: In Fig. 5.26, lines l and m are parallel. If ∠8 is 135°, then ∠2 is also 135° because they are linear pairs.
Example 2: In Fig. 5.27, lines l and m are intersected by the transversal t. If ∠a is 120° and ∠f is 70°, are lines l and m parallel to each other?

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of interior angles and their properties.
Students will be able to identify and measure interior angles in different scenarios.
Students will learn to apply the concept of interior angles to solve problems involving parallel lines and transversals.

content_blocks.text: Interior angles are the angles formed by a transversal intersecting two or more lines and are on the same side of the transversal.
When a transversal intersects two or more lines, it forms interior angles on the same side of the transversal. These angles are supplementary to each other.
Example 1: In Fig. 5.28, parallel lines l and m are intersected by the transversal t. If ∠3 is 50°, what is the measure of ∠6?
Example 2: In Fig. 5.29, line segment AB is parallel to CD and AD is parallel to BC. ∠DAC is 65° and ∠ADC is 60°. What are the measures of angles ∠CAB, ∠ABC, and ∠BCD?

learning_objectives: Students will understand the concept of angles and parallel lines.
Students will be able to identify and measure angles in different situations.
Students will learn to recognize and apply the properties of parallel lines.

content_blocks.text: When two lines intersect, they form four angles. The vertically opposite angles are equal and the linear pairs add up to 180°.
When two lines intersect and the angles formed are 90° (i.e., all four angles are equal), the lines are said to be perpendicular to each other.
In Fig. 5.3, list all the linear pairs and vertically opposite angles you observe.
When two lines never intersect on a plane, they are called parallel lines.
When a line t intersects another pair of lines, it is called a transversal and it forms 2 sets of 4 angles.
In Fig. 5.6, which pairs of lines appear to be parallel?

learning_objectives: Students will understand the properties of parallel lines and their relationship with perpendicular lines.
Students will be able to identify and draw parallel lines in different orientations.
Students will learn to recognize the pattern of parallel lines formed by folding a sheet of paper.

content_blocks.text: Fold the sheet horizontally in half. A new line is formed (see Fig. 5.7).
How many parallel lines do you see now? How does the new line segment relate to the vertical sides?
We will see three parallel lines. The new line segment is perpendicular to the vertical sides.
After one more horizontal fold, we will see a total of five parallel lines. The two original horizontal edges, the first fold line, and the second fold line are all parallel to each other.
If we fold it horizontally one more time, we will get nine parallel lines. Yes, the pattern is 2n + 1, where n is the number of folds.
This new vertical line is perpendicular to the previous horizontal lines.
Yes, we can find a fold that creates a line parallel to the diagonal line.
The opposite edges of the sheet are parallel to each other. The adjacent edges of the sheet are perpendicular to each other.
Line segments a, b and c are parallel to Line segments p, q and r respectively.

learning_objectives: Students will understand the relationship between folding a sheet of paper and parallel lines.
Students will be able to identify and draw parallel lines using folding techniques.
Students will learn to recognize the properties of parallel lines formed by folding a sheet of paper.

content_blocks.text: Take a square sheet of paper, fold it in the middle and unfold it.
Fold the edges towards the centre line and unfold them.
Fold the top right and bottom left corners onto the creased line to create triangles. Refer to Fig. 5.8.
The triangles should not cross the crease lines.
Are a, b and c parallel to p, q and r respectively? Why or why not?

learning_objectives: Students will understand how to identify parallel lines in different orientations.
Students will be able to recognize the properties of parallel lines.
Students will learn to draw different sets of parallel lines.

content_blocks.text: Draw some lines perpendicular to the lines given on the dot paper in the Figure.
How did you spot the perpendicular lines?
The vertical and horizontal lines on the grid paper meet at a 90-degree angle (a right angle)
By identifying lines that always remain the same distance apart.
Line segments a, b and c are parallel to Line segments p, q and r respectively.

learning_objectives: Students will understand the properties of angles.
Students will be able to identify and apply the properties of angles to solve problems.
Students will learn to use the properties of angles to find missing angles.

content_blocks.text: Complementary angles are two angles whose measures add up to 90°.
Supplementary angles are two angles whose measures add up to 180°.
In the figure below, ∠1 and ∠2 are complementary angles. Find the measure of ∠2.
In the figure below, ∠3 and ∠4 are supplementary angles. Find the measure of ∠4.
In the figure below, ∠5 and ∠6 are adjacent angles. Find the measure of ∠6.
In the figure below, ∠7 and ∠8 are interior angles. Find the measure of ∠8.
In the figure below, ∠9 and ∠10 are exterior angles. Find the measure of ∠10.
